channel.title: Using NodeJS as a platform
channel.description:
Anyone thought to use NodeJS for a server? I think it would be a great platform to use. You could technically split apart your services across multiple services. Eg: Control of a world to a RESTful service.
I thought about it the other idea and most servers (because RSPS isn't as massive as say enterprise applications) don't follow master/slave model. Even sharding/clustering. I think that'd be interesting to design :)

item.title: Using NodeJS as a platform
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:37, topic:546413”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=665312.msg4447607#msg4447607 date=1409680771]
I have a semi-functioning RSC server written for NodeJS. It isn’t very efficient at all, but I liked exploring ideas on how to structure things.

EDIT: To Lothy, you don’t theoretically even need a tick system. You could write the entire server with events.
[/quote]ya ok thanks for the credit; i practically wrote the entire thing[/quote]not true, you didn’t want to help until i had something interesting

Read full topic

item.title: Using NodeJS as a platform
item.dc:creator: @Metho_D Method
item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:28, topic:546413”]Can you share your quadtree code sinisoul?

EDIT:

[quote author=Lothy link=topic=665312.msg4447562#msg4447562 date=1409653620]Simpler still, you could sort players using a comparator that orders them by their x and y co-ordinates (something like x << 16 | y).
In a world that is 10x10 cartesian points, and a search that looks up to d=2 from the player, you would loop through the points like so:
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d o o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d o o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d o o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d P d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o o d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o o d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o o d d d d o o o[/font]

If you’re looking for players within 2 tiles of ‘P’, why not just look at the 5x5 square centered at ‘P’? I’m not sure I follow why the other ‘d’ tiles are examined.
[/quote]
Because that’s the result of depending on the subMap(K fromKey, boolean fromInclusive, K toKey, boolean toInclusive) method in the NavigableMap interface with a comparator ordering entities by x << 16 | y or y << 16 x.
The point of that example was to demonstrate that you can, extremely simply, achieve a modest performance gain over O(n) naive looping by simply using the TreeMap’s inherent ordering.[/quote]

Gotcha, thanks for clearing that up.

Sorry for hijacking your thread sini.

Read full topic

item.title: Using NodeJS as a platform
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:26, topic:546413”]I mean. You don’t have to be on the cutting edge. Generators are nice but I feel like you could use the fibers package if you wanted to for that.[/quote]The nice part about generators is that they already work with all the existing callback-ridden modules on npmjs.org with most generator modules (co, suspend, etc.) with exactly the same performance and still all within the same thread.

[quote=“sinisoul, post:22, topic:546413”]Well yeah but it’s hidden for the most part. What problems nerd?! HM?![/quote]Amibiguity problems. Look at each and tell me which is faster to comprehend.

I’d say both JS options would be easier on the eyes (but the second maybe more performant).

I’ve came across other small annoyances and it always takes me longer to read through Coffeescript modules.

Read full topic

item.title: Using NodeJS as a platform
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Cool. I’ll post benchmarks later (and the code to produce those benchmarks).

EDIT 2: Disregard previous benchmarks. In practice the TreeMap solution I proposed must store cartesian points (that is, ActiveTile, Tile, Point or whatever) as it can’t have the key for what it stores changing constantly (this would ruin the sorting).
So that means you have a huge memory overhead, and the search space is actually huge too. The benchmark is actually very shit:

----------
Max X=2000, Max Y=2000
Distance = 30
Number of points that we’re finding within-distance neighbours = 5000

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 102 ms (searching 1000 points, result size=2)
TreeMapPointFinder - Elapsed time: 11160 ms (searching 1000 points, result size=2)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 17 ms (searching 1000 points, result size=2)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 769 ms (searching 10000 points, result size=6)
TreeMapPointFinder - Elapsed time: 10901 ms (searching 10000 points, result size=6)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 36 ms (searching 10000 points, result size=6)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 6954 ms (searching 100000 points, result size=84)
TreeMapPointFinder - Elapsed time: 10639 ms (searching 100000 points, result size=84)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 175 ms (searching 100000 points, result size=84)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 77997 ms (searching 1000000 points, result size=785)
TreeMapPointFinder - Elapsed time: 12871 ms (searching 1000000 points, result size=785)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 1766 ms (searching 1000000 points, result size=785)

Here’s one without the TreeMapPointFinder:

[font=verdana]----------[/font]
Max X=7000, Max Y=7000
Distance = 30
Number of points that we’re finding within-distance neighbours = 5000

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 92 ms (searching 1000 points, result size=0)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 14 ms (searching 1000 points, result size=0)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 569 ms (searching 10000 points, result size=0)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 4 ms (searching 10000 points, result size=0)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 1082 ms (searching 20000 points, result size=0)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 4 ms (searching 20000 points, result size=0)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 3643 ms (searching 50000 points, result size=2)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 8 ms (searching 50000 points, result size=2)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 6381 ms (searching 100000 points, result size=7)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 34 ms (searching 100000 points, result size=7)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 31828 ms (searching 500000 points, result size=42)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 66 ms (searching 500000 points, result size=42)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 60691 ms (searching 1000000 points, result size=59)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 78 ms (searching 1000000 points, result size=59)

ListIterationPointFinder - Elapsed time: 130836 ms (searching 2000000 points, result size=136)
RegionPointFinder - Elapsed time: 322 ms (searching 2000000 points, result size=136)
Anyway, share your quad tree and I’ll try to incorporate it in this benchmark. In any case, it’s pretty clear that even static space partitioning is extremely beneficial.

Read full topic

item.title: Using NodeJS as a platform
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Can you share your quadtree code sinisoul?

EDIT:

[quote=“Method, post:14, topic:546413”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=665312.msg4447562#msg4447562 date=1409653620]Simpler still, you could sort players using a comparator that orders them by their x and y co-ordinates (something like x << 16 | y).
In a world that is 10x10 cartesian points, and a search that looks up to d=2 from the player, you would loop through the points like so:
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d o o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d o o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d o o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d P d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o d d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o o d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o o d d d d o o o[/font]
[font=verdana]o o o o d d d d o o o[/font]
[/quote]

If you’re looking for players within 2 tiles of ‘P’, why not just look at the 5x5 square centered at ‘P’? I’m not sure I follow why the other ‘d’ tiles are examined.[/quote]
Because that’s the result of depending on the subMap(K fromKey, boolean fromInclusive, K toKey, boolean toInclusive) method in the NavigableMap interface with a comparator ordering entities by x << 16 | y or y << 16 x.
The point of that example was to demonstrate that you can, extremely simply, achieve a modest performance gain over O(n) naive looping by simply using the TreeMap’s inherent ordering.

Read full topic

item.title: Using NodeJS as a platform
item.dc:creator: @Death_Style Death Style
item.description:
@Death_Style wrote:

I’d want to have all the new features, especially if I’m working server code. CS policy seems that if IE6 doesn’t support it then they won’t add it. which means even if you’re writing on the server don’t expect to use getters/setters which are pretty useful imo

again, all gimmicks you could imitate but freezing CS in the past while ECMA adds to the specification is going to leave out a lot of handy additions in the future

Read full topic

I mean. You don’t have to be on the cutting edge. Generators are nice but I feel like you could use the fibers package if you wanted to for that.

item.description:
@Death_Style wrote:

I don’t actually use coffeescript but from what I remember was certain loops in CS are named similarly to new loops in ES6, the escape character for embedding javascript in coffeescript is the same character they’re proposing for quasi-literals, and there isn’t support for generators

trying to find the discussion where I read some of them

Read full topic

item.title: Using NodeJS as a platform
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:20, topic:546413”]Fucking burn javascripts stupid ass prototype with fire.[/quote]It still uses prototypal inheirtance. ES6 is brining pretty much the same syntax sugar. CoffeeScrip goes too far IMO, it looks ridiculous and causes problems.

Anyway yeah I can see this being an excellent platform. You could integrate pretty much whatever REST service interactions you want, and release APIs that interact on port 80 for the live game. It’s not like you can’t do this with other platforms, but in JS it sure is nice. There’s a lot of potential with it.

Read full topic
